page.title: 02History of Sedlescombe
page.content: This area consists of beautiful unspoilt countryside containing the villages of Sedlescombe and Whatlington. A village existed here long before Norman times. Remains have been found of early ironworks. It is believed that iron was worked in this area well before Roman times. The iron industry thrived during the Roman occupation. The manufacturing of gunpowder also grew here. It is only in the last 150 years Sedlescombe has assumed its present rural and placid village nature. In 1831 the population of Sedlescombe was 732 and it was now a farming area. Other occupations were charcoal burning and making hop poles. Around the village green were three blacksmiths, a bootmaker, a carpenter's yard, a butcher, a toyshop, an art gallery and a Methodist chapel.
